Co-routines are the "dirty little secret" of #programming

A language has to implement runtime code to match what the hardware can do
duff's device , #Knuth and coroutines in C
https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/coroutines.html

some architectures are created JUST to make it easy for C to be simple to implement and offer nothing else
It is somewhat ironic that C was developed on the #PDP-9 family of computers which also has the same co-routine mechanism as they are "cousin" machines.  But that aspect of the architecture is conspicuously not present in the #compiler language.
#PASCAL superficially resembles PL/I and has some work-alikes to that, but it is a "hollow" equivalent and lacks many features because it has an agenda
#DECtape is a physically serial implementation of a block-replaceable dismountable #harddisk
Just being "equivalent" in your head doesn't cut it.  Youhave to be able to define one in the other, that doesn't happen. #superlike
you cannot express the runtime out of the compiler as just two instructions #pdp
The more often a piece of programming is actually used, the more efficient it ought to be to avoid overhead
You cannot get the code that REALLY must be optimized to be so unless it is written in assmbler..  Knuth and that principle wins the argument.
What % if programmers can tell sub routines from coroutines , w/o seeking any reference ?
Servicing file functions creates incredibly tiny sections of code by co-routines can be called as library calls
If you like compilers, you will never be able to write code like a skilled assembly person,
code even shorter, a valid techinique is self-referential code
Don't take brownie points for every little thing

Many Cretan Muslims were resettled in Libya by the Ottomans when Crete passed from Ottoman province to autonomous province to part of Greece in the period between 1898 and 1912. Almost all are Libyan citizens. Anyone who can prove his male ancestor left Crete AFTER 1908 may have a legitimate claim to Greek #citizenship.

comment.body: @Realjohndoe: Twitter's content discovery is very powerful , some facebook groups are hangouts of bare metal programmers , I am not fan of either twitter or FB , because of multiple features , but bothseem to have developed some features which are unlikely  to be matched by others due to history or other reasons, like size of community, bandwidth  of server farms, social impact of celebrities ... I mean I can't see many politicians of world pulling up a terminal and actually running zeronet.py , they are just not that tech savvy, but their updates make news and news is indispensable feature of social media, we mostly comment on the news ...
@Version: Can't see your comment, could you repost it , thanks

@Realjohndoe: at an exponential rate
are there numbers/statistics to back that ?

[@Sameer:](?Profile/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF/sameer@zeroid.bit "mention:1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF") fallacy of higher-level language is that it is NOT capable of simplying what machines really do

it is just enough of a language to implement a one-pass [with fixups] compilation of itself written in itself, and by  deliberate design.  This was so a baby compiler study course could be created, but you never learn about the "hard stuff" etc
IBM used decimal hardware crap   to sell otherwise unneeded hardware

[@Sameer:](?Profile/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF/sameer@zeroid.bit "mention:1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF") Assert macro checks for the validity of the assertions or assumptions. If the assertion results to be FALSE then the macro writes information about the call that failed on stderr and then calls abort(). abort() raises the SIGABRT signal and this results in an abnormal termination of the process #c

[@Sameer:](?Profile/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF/sameer@zeroid.bit "mention:1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF") set the limits of the operation using Blitter Copy Limit.
One source   : the bitplane is copies normally             (=%11110000).
Two sources  : the bitplanes are combined using logical OR (=%11111100).
Three sources: the bitplanes are combined using logical OR (=%11111110).
Frequently used miniterm values:

Sourceplanes one, two and three represent A, B and C.

1: %11110000: copy bitplane                 : A
1: %00001111: invert bitplane               : NOT A
2: %11111100: use logical OR on the planes  : A OR B
2: %00000011: OR planes and invert them     : NOT (A OR B)
#amiga

[@Sameer:](?Profile/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF/sameer@zeroid.bit "mention:1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF")  On an Amiga computer the video picture is created by so called bitplanes. These are linear blocks in chip memory, of which every single bit represents one dot on the screen.

[@Sameer:](?Profile/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF/sameer@zeroid.bit "mention:1PyXS9BpytiuWuoscnwwR3AfF7kxjWCJZF") You can get the pointer to the single bitplanes using Logbase(planenr) and Phybase(planenr).

Also everyone has different objectives/ motives for learning the same thing . 
If they are met, does it really matter how that fits to some other scale?
